details.title: A New Inverted U-Shape Hazard Function

p: Tal Avinadav holds a B.Sc. In Industrial Engineering; and an M.B.A., and a Ph.D. In Management, all from Tel-Aviv University. He is a lecturer of Industrial Engineering and Operations Research at the Department of Logistics at Bar-Ilan University. Previously, he managed a Production Planning & Control Department in the IAF. In the last three years, he has served as consultant to several public organizations in Israel on project and operations management.

Tzvi Raz holds B.Sc., M.A.Sc., and Ph.D. degrees in Industrial and Management Engineering. He is a Professor of Technology and Information Systems Management at the Leon Recanati Graduate School of Business Administration at Tel-Aviv University and currently serves as Associate Dean of the Faculty. Previously, he managed a technology insertion program at an IBM software development laboratory, and was on the Industrial Engineering faculties of the University of Iowa, US; and Ben Gurion University, Israel. Dr. Raz has published over 60 research papers in refereed international journals. In the last ten years, he has served as consultant to several technology firms in Israel on project and risk management, and has conducted short courses and workshops on these topics in Israel, Europe and South America.

details.abstract: The hazard function describes the unobserved rate at which failures occur. In this paper, we present a new inverted U-shape hazard function, developed for risk-events related to human activities. This hazard shape has received less attention in the literature relative to monotone hazard functions, likely due to the mathematical complexity of their regression models. We present a new survivor function, based on a logarithm transformation, and time displacement of Weibull's survivor function, that has an inverted U-shape hazard function similar to the log-logistic one. The advantage of this hazard function relative to the Weibull, and log-logistic hazard functions is in its unique curvature, which may fit better in some cases. We use simulation studies to present the new distribution characteristics in comparison to the Weibull, and the log-logistic distributions.

references.title: Event History Analysis

context.text: The common techniques to model dynamic failure behavior are described in Kalbfleisch & Prentice [5], Lawless [6], Cox & Oakes [3], and Allison [1] among others.

Allison [1] indicates that an inverted U-shape hazard function may be fit for describing social mobility, in which there is an initial “resting period” after the previous move, an increase of the risk of a move as the resting period is completed, and a decline in the risk of a move as individuals become more invested in a particular social location.

references.text: P. D. Allison, Event History Analysis, 1984, Sage.

A reliability distribution with increasing,
decreasing, constant and bathtub-shaped failure rates

context.text: Nevertheless, Hjorth [4] claims that the bathtub hazard curve can represent the reliability of a mixture of mechanical units with quality variations.
A new reliability distribution with three parameters, which is flexible like the Weibull distribution, and with the capacity to also describe a U-shape hazard function, is described in [4].

references.text: U. Hjorth, "A reliability distribution with increasing decreasing constant and bathtub-shaped failure rates", Technometrics, vol. 22, no. 1, pp. 99-107, 1980.

references.title: Statistical Models and Methods for Life Time Data

context.text: The common techniques to model dynamic failure behavior are described in Kalbfleisch & Prentice [5], Lawless [6], Cox & Oakes [3], and Allison [1] among others.
Two of the most common inverted U-shape hazard functions in the literature are the lognormal, and the log-logistic models, described in [6].
Survival models based on the Weibull, or the log-logistic distributions are members of another general class of models called accelerated failure time models [5], or location models [6].

references.text: J. F. Lawless, Statistical Models and Methods for Life Time Data, 1982, John Wiley & Sons.
